documents.title: GoC H1 2026 Product Prioritization - WIP
documents.content:
Ôªø2026 Strategy

FTEs: 8 devs (3 parental fill, 2 backfills) ‚Üí Q2 7 FE devs (+ 1EM +2 POs) + [new] 2 FE devs + 1 BE 

H2 2025 Reflection

In H2 2025, our product strategy was designed to address unrecovered Conversion Rates (CR) and declining Active Order Rates (AOR). For CR, we successfully launched the Reactivation page revamp and are on progress to launch the One Time Purchase experiment. On the AOR side, we drove Free Add-on take rates to over 90% consistently by closing gaps in the selection and persistence experience, and launched Charge at Checkout.

1. Reactivation Page Revamp. We launched a new, mobile-first reactivation page that reduces the page length by one third with improvements on information architecture and clearer call to action. Also, customers can now choose their free add-ons directly on the reactivation page, instead of after reactivating their accounts. These changes are foundational to run more free for life reactivation campaigns including turkeys on Thanksgiving  (+20% CR YoY). However, some critical features were de-prioritized such as the ability to change cadence and reschedule directly on the reactivation page. 

2. One-Time Purchases (OTP). The technical solution for OTP pivoted from the initial MVP hack to the proper solution due to a technical blocker from CRM as well as higher confidence in the new endpoint following HF rollouts. While this solution saves time in the long-term, the launch week is delayed (likely W2‚Äô2026 - TBC) due to additional time for another technical investigation and (unplanned) capacity constraints.

3. Closing Free Add-on Take Rate. By October we finally reached +90% free add-on take rate for both new and active users consistently. Persisting free add-ons (+40% active TR), developing the multi-add-on pop-up on funnel and reactivation (+5% TR), and migrating bundle offers to Wallet (4.2k customers). While it‚Äôs great that we finally closed down the Wallet take rate gap, a significant portion of Q3 engineering capacity was allocated, which was not originally accounted for in the H2 roadmap.

4. Charge at Checkout. By charging customers at checkout instead of at cut-off, we aim to improve empty conversions and acceptance rates, thereby positively impacting overall delivered orders.





Learnings: 

* Better resource planning for adhoc and technical initiatives needed: We only executed on 2 out of 5 key strategies referenced in the previous strategy document with projects such as the Pricing Value Experiment getting pushed to next year. When planning for H2 2025, we did not initially account for initiatives such as Subscribable free add ons, as well as more tactical initiatives like 2-week cadence or legal compliance initiatives in the (cancellation) funnel. Engineering capacity was also impacted around September-October due to personnel changes, including one transfer to TPT and two individuals taking parental leave. We also need to proactively account for resourcing technical initiatives such as endpoint deprecations and migrations.

* More space needed for iterations: there are initiatives such as Seamless and Search with clear next iterations, however instead of building these we focused on building new initiatives. This delays implementing these learnings and therefore realization of business value. Doing these next iterations with too much time in between can also lengthen development as the team has to re-learn the technical context for the next iteration, or as previous feature leads churn from the team.









Good Chop 2026 Product Strategy

Q1 2026: Closing the Gaps an



ith new delivery options with 1 day cutoff

[p]i think this should be dependent on OTP leads results

[q]how come? I don't think the learnings from Leads test will necessarily transfer





It could work better because cancelled customers might have already experienced first-hand that subscription does not work 





We could even think about targeting specifically customers that have churned due to delivery frequency reasons

[r]-> hesitation more from a BC perspective + no ability to discount





-> refer to HF test learnings

[s]~10% cancel for "lifestyle" reason (="sub doens't work for me")

[t]1 total reaction

Yury Trofimov reacted with üòò at 2025-12-02 19:28 PM

[u]that can be a significant lever for AOR and PC2 improvement, should we move fw knowing that part of it will be unlocked with the value test

[v]open to continuing price/value exp hack

[w]lay out limitations with hacks (eg roll out strategy)

[x]1 total reaction

Marina Guthmann reacted with ‚ô•Ô∏è at 2025-12-03 15:40 PM

[y]potentially already planned for CDP v2 to fix data lag

[z]it would be interesting to sequence the rebranding with value driven initiatives, such as richer PDPs. so we can collaborate with mktg on how to tackle the changes' communications

[aa]in the end if we want to do this well and continue highlighting new products, new deals, we eventually need to find a way to showcase surcharge cuts pre-checkout





I'm wondering if we should re-test surcharge pre-checkout but as its own section/maybe even bringing the 2-step flow pre-checkout 





because if we find a good way to frame surcharge cuts and Deals pre-checkout, then we will have more merchandising we can do pre-checkout as well





EOS+transparent pricing also a criteria

[ab]already big reasons to buy for prospects - we could target this to actives

[ac]in the end if we want to do this well and continue highlighting new products, new deals, we eventually need to find a way to showcase surcharge cuts pre-checkout





I'm wondering if we should re-test surcharge pre-checkout but as its own section/maybe even bringing the 2-step flow pre-checkout 





because if we find a good way to frame surcharge cuts and Deals pre-checkout, then we will have more merchandising we can do pre-checkout as well





EOS+transparent pricing also a criteria

[ad]already big reasons to buy for prospects - we could target this to actives

documents.content:
Ôªø2026 Strategy

FTEs: 8 devs (3 parental fill, 2 backfills) ‚Üí Q2 7 FE devs (+ 1EM +2 POs) + [new] 2 FE devs + 1 BE 

Q1: 7 FE devs (Himash, Becca, Romi, Pame, Nvard, Chi, Madeeha)

Q2: +2 FE devs, +Bolo & Richa back (11 total FEs), 1 BE (TBD)

H2 2025 Reflection

In H2 2025, our product strategy was designed to address unrecovered Conversion Rates (CR) and declining Active Order Rates (AOR). For CR, we successfully launched the Reactivation page revamp and are on progress to launch the One Time Purchase experiment. However, some critical features were de-prioritized such as the ability to change cadence and reschedule directly on the reactivation page.

The technical solution for OTP pivoted from the initial MVP hack to the proper solution due to a technical blocker from CRM as well as higher confidence in the new endpoint following HF rollouts. While this solution saves time in the long-term, the launch week is delayed (likely W2‚Äô2026 - TBC) due to additional time for another technical investigation and (unplanned) capacity constraints.

3. Closing Free Add-on Take Rate. By October we finally reached +90% free add-on take rate for both new and active users consistently. Persisting free add-ons (+40% active TR), developing the multi-add-on pop-up on funnel and reactivation (+5% TR), and migrating bundle offers to Wallet (4.2k customers). While it‚Äôs great that we finally closed down the Wallet take rate gap, a significant portion of Q3 engineering capacity was allocated, which was not originally accounted for in the H2 roadmap.

4. Charge at Checkout. By charging customers at checkout instead of at cut-off, we aim to improve empty conversions and acceptance rates, thereby positively impacting overall delivered orders.

When planning for H2 2025, we did not initially account for initiatives such as Subscribable free add ons, as well as more tactical initiatives like 2-week cadence or legal compliance initiatives in the (cancellation) funnel. Engineering capacity was also impacted around September-October due to personnel changes, including one transfer to TPT and two individuals taking parental leave. We also need to proactively account for resourcing technical initiatives such as endpoint deprecations and migrations.

* More space needed for iterations: there are initiatives such as Seamless and Search with clear next iterations, however instead of building these we focused on building new initiatives. This delays implementing these learnings and therefore realization of business value. Doing these next iterations with too much time in between can also lengthen development as the team has to re-learn the technical context for the next iter



al: Plans renaming

[b]Any payment initiatives we should add?

[c]bnpl? :eyes:

[d]does ProcessOut unlock better capabilities (eg express checkout; bnpl)?





tbc cc @nikita.gorshkov@hellofresh.com

[e]More directly in our control: Payment failures experience in Actives experience





refer back to separate Payments discussions eg payment re-try

[f]We had discussed the delivery date picker test. Similarly, testing faster shipping to increase CVR

[g]it's here below the line

[h]plan in OTP for Actives? small lift if it's just about re-directing to a Plans page and exposing an OTP option only?

[i]if the results are positive, we'd still need significant effort to make it scalable from the data perspective. right now we'd be driving in the blind and rely on adhoc analysis, which is fine for the test but not ok for scaling marketing. basically it fully kills bob attribution based on vouchers

[j]depending on estimations we might de-prio this 





bigger upside for %-based discounts 





data on how many LL0 customers add Deals/Premium after?

[k]pre-requisite for later removing Plans page

[l]Ideally we only take this up once funnel clean up is done

[m]currently placed below the line despite bigger BC than Raf because we have already seen some improvements this year (+19% in Gross RR YoY, +14% in Net RR YoY)

[n]is it due to the new page? do we have pre/post?

[o]i think this should be dependent on OTP leads results

[p]how come? I don't think the learnings from Leads test will necessarily transfer





It could work better because cancelled customers might have already experienced first-hand that subscription does not work 





We could even think about targeting specifically customers that have churned due to delivery frequency reasons

[q]-> hesitation more from a BC perspective + no ability to discount





-> refer to HF test learnings

[r]~10% cancel for "lifestyle" reason (="sub doens't work for me")

[s]1 total reaction

Yury Trofimov reacted with üòò at 2025-12-02 19:28 PM

[t]that can be a significant lever for AOR and PC2 improvement, should we move fw knowing that part of it will be unlocked with the value test

[u]open to continuing price/value exp hack

[v]lay out limitations with hacks (eg roll out strategy)

[w]1 total reaction

Marina Guthmann reacted with ‚ô•Ô∏è at 2025-12-03 15:40 PM

[x]potentially already planned for CDP v2 to fix data lag
